alert.note: Alert for Santa Barbara County Southeastern Coast; Santa Barbara County Southwestern Coast (California) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued December 22 at 1:53AM PST until December 24 at 12:00PM PST by NWS Oxnard
info.description: ...HIGHEST TIDES OF THE YEAR...OR KING TIDES...WILL CAUSE PERIODS OF MINOR TIDAL OVERFLOWS AND INCREASED RIP CURRENT ACTIVITY EARLY FRIDAY THROUGH MIDDAY SATURDAY... .The highest astronomical tides of the year, or King Tides, will affect areas beaches and coastlines the next several mornings when high tide is forecast to occur. King tides have historically resulted in the minor flooding of beach walkways and normal dry beach areas and increased rip current activity. The period of greatest threat of minor coastal flooding looks to be between early Friday through midday Saturday. ...BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM LATE TONIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Dangerous rip currents and breaking waves due to elevated surf of 3 to 6 feet expected. Abnormally high tides around 7 feet are expected each morning between Friday and Saturday. Minor tidal overflow is possible around the time of morning high tide. * WHERE...Santa Barbara County Southwestern Coast and Santa Barbara County Southeastern Coast. * WHEN...From late tonight through Saturday morning. * IMPACTS...Pooling of sea water is possible around high tide at beach and harbor areas that is uncommon with normal tidal ranges. Enhanced beach erosion is also possible. No significant damage is expected. There is an increased risk of ocean drowning due to increased rip current activity. Rip currents can pull swimmers and surfers out to sea. Waves can wash people off beaches and rocks, and capsize small boats nearshore. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Morning high tides of over 7 feet are forecast for Friday and Saturday between 8 and 9 am local time.
info.instruction: Avoid flooded walkways and beaches. Remain out of the water due to hazardous swimming conditions, or stay near occupied lifeguard towers, if available. Rock jetties can be deadly in such conditions, stay off the rocks.

area.areaDesc: Santa Barbara County Southeastern Coast; Santa Barbara County Southwestern Coast
